awd_titl_txt: 2022 Correlated Electron Electron Systems: Topology and Correlations: Long-Range Entanglement in Many-Body Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Gordon Research Conference on Correlated Electron Systems provides an opportunity for scientists, especially graduate students and postdoctoral students, to learn and to be exposed to the latest developments in correlated electron materials. The biannual occurrence of these meetings is well-suited to the rapid pace of discovery in the physics of quantum and strongly correlated materials. The unique climate of Gordon Research Conferences, which encourage the presentation of unpublished, cutting-edge developments, while also promoting an informal, friendly atmosphere in which attendees, particularly students and postdocs, can gain ready access to world experts in the field, make this a very attractive meeting. Moreover, the low-cost accommodation at Mount Holyoke college, and the close vicinity of the meeting to institutions in the North-East and Mid-west, make this a meeting that is geographically and financially accessible to a large number of students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Topology and Correlations: Long-Range Entanglement in Many-Body Systems

Duration: June 26 - July 1, 2022
The Gordon conference was held in Mt. Holyoke and attended by over 200 participants. The topics included (1) Correlated phases in twisted bilayer graphene and transition metal compounds. By twisting these materials produce very narrow flatbands that are highly susceptible to various types of correlated phases. (2) Frustrated magnetism and quantum spin liquid phases. These systems are unable to order and lead to highly entangled states with fractionalized excitations that can be utilized for topologically protected computations. (3) Transport in non-Fermi liquids. Once interactions dominate, electrons no longer behave like quasiparticles and lead to anomalous signatures in thermodynamics and transport. (4) Quantum Dynamics and Measurement.
Some of the highlights were the following:
(A) a panel discussion session with speakers presenting conflicting data on the podium and active particpation by the audience
(B) The discussion sessions were organized into breakout groups so more people could get involved and discuss, rether than only a few people dominating the questions and discussions.
(C) Power Hour: Led by Colette Patt (UC Berkeley) on improving diversity and inclusion at all stages in academia and the challenges. 
(D) Late breaking topics on new platforms for creating correlated and topological materials.
(E) Poster sessions that ran till midnight with active particpation by all attendees. 
(F) The Discussion Leaders summarized the field and provided a broad perspective (as opposed to a more limited summary of the talks in that session, as done usually). 
Overall a very successful meeting based on feedback and active participation.
